metadata.subject: physics
metadata.dotPoint: analyse the supply of power by considering transmission losses across transmission lines

power_transmission_components.name: Power Transmission Components
power_transmission_components.correct: A power transmission system consists of a power supply/generator, transmission lines with resistance, and a load.

only the generator and load.fix: Real transmission lines have resistance that causes voltage drop and power loss.
only the generator and load.action: Draw the complete circuit: generator → lines (with R) → load.

generator and transformer only.error: Missing the transmission lines and load.
generator and transformer only.fix: Power flows: generator → step-up transformer → lines → step-down transformer → load.
generator and transformer only.action: Trace the path electricity takes from power station to your home.

parallel circuits.error: Transmission systems are modelled as series circuits.
parallel circuits.fix: Current flows through generator, lines, and load in series.
parallel circuits.action: In series, same current flows through all components.

persistent.gap: You don't understand the basic power transmission model.
persistent.action: Draw 5 complete transmission diagrams with all components labelled.

voltage_drop_formula.name: Voltage Drop Formula
voltage_drop_formula.correct: Voltage drop across transmission lines: Vdrop = IlineRline (Ohm's law applied to the lines).

Vdrop = Iline/Rline.error: Wrong operation. Ohm's law uses multiplication.
Vdrop = Iline/Rline.fix: V = IR means V = I × R, not I ÷ R.
Vdrop = Iline/Rline.action: Check units: A × Ω = V. Does A/Ω give volts?

Vdrop = Vsupply − Vload.error: That calculates voltage drop but doesn't explain its cause.
Vdrop = Vsupply − Vload.fix: The formula Vdrop = IlineRline shows WHY there's a drop: current through resistance.
Vdrop = Vsupply − Vload.action: Both are correct. One is a calculation, the other is the physics.

Vdrop = Pline/Iline.error: That's derived from P = VI, not the direct formula.
Vdrop = Pline/Iline.fix: Primary formula is Vdrop = IlineRline. P/I is a valid alternative.
Vdrop = Pline/Iline.action: Know both: Vdrop = IR and Vdrop = P/I (from P = VI).

persistent.gap: You're not confident with Ohm's law applications.
persistent.action: Calculate voltage drops for 5 different current/resistance combinations.

power_loss_formula.name: Power Loss Formula
power_loss_formula.correct: Power loss in transmission lines: Ploss = I²lineRline. Current is squared, making it the dominant factor.

Ploss = IlineRline.fix: Power loss = I²R, not IR. The current must be squared.
Ploss = IlineRline.action: Check units: A² × Ω = A² × V/A = A × V = W.

Ploss = V²line/Rline.error: Vline is the supply voltage, not the voltage drop.
Ploss = V²line/Rline.fix: Use Ploss = Vdrop × Iline or Ploss = I²lineRline. V²/R uses the drop, not supply.
Ploss = V²line/Rline.action: Ploss = V²drop/Rline works, but V must be the DROP across the lines.

Ploss = Psupply − Pload.error: That calculates loss but doesn't explain its cause.
Ploss = Psupply − Pload.fix: The formula Ploss = I²R shows WHY power is lost: current heating resistance.
Ploss = Psupply − Pload.action: Both valid. One is calculation, the other is physics.

Ploss = IlineVline.error: That would use supply voltage, not voltage drop.
Ploss = IlineVline.fix: Ploss = Iline × Vdrop, where Vdrop is across the lines, not the supply.
Ploss = IlineVline.action: P = IV works, but I and V must be for the same component.

persistent.gap: You're confusing power formulas and their applications.
persistent.action: Write P = I²R, P = VI, P = V²/R. Practice when to use each.

current_squared_effect.name: Current Squared Effect
current_squared_effect.correct: Doubling current quadruples power loss because Ploss = I²R. The squared relationship makes current the critical factor.

doubles power loss.fix: 2× current → 2² = 4× power loss. 3× current → 9× power loss.
doubles power loss.action: Calculate: if I = 2 A gives Ploss = 8 W, what does I = 4 A give?

halves power loss.error: Opposite direction. More current = more loss.
halves power loss.fix: Higher current means MORE power dissipated as heat in the wires.
halves power loss.action: P = I²R. Bigger I → bigger P. It's a positive relationship.

has no effect on power loss.error: Current is the dominant factor in power loss.
has no effect on power loss.fix: P = I²R shows current directly determines power loss.
has no effect on power loss.action: Why do we transmit at high voltage? To reduce current and thus I² losses.

persistent.gap: You don't understand squared relationships in physics.
persistent.action: Make a table: I, I², Ploss for I = 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 A with R = 10 Ω.

voltage_load_formula.name: Voltage at Load
voltage_load_formula.correct: The load receives less voltage than supplied because some is 'used up' across the transmission line resistance.

Vload = Vsupply + Vdrop.error: Voltage is lost, not gained, in the lines.
Vload = Vsupply + Vdrop.fix: Voltage drop SUBTRACTS from supply voltage.
Vload = Vsupply + Vdrop.action: If 100 V supplied and 10 V dropped, load gets 100 − 10 = 90 V.

Vload = Vsupply × Vdrop.error: Wrong operation. Voltages add/subtract in series circuits.
Vload = Vsupply × Vdrop.fix: In series: Vsupply = Vdrop + Vload, so Vload = Vsupply − Vdrop.
Vload = Vsupply × Vdrop.action: Apply Kirchhoff's voltage law around the circuit.

Vload = Vsupply.error: Ignoring the voltage drop across the lines.
Vload = Vsupply.fix: Real lines have resistance → voltage drop → less voltage at load.
Vload = Vsupply.action: Only true if Rline = 0, which never happens in real systems.

persistent.gap: You're not applying Kirchhoff's voltage law correctly.
persistent.action: Draw circuit, label all voltages, verify they sum to zero around the loop.

power_load_formula.name: Power Delivered to Load
power_load_formula.correct: Power delivered to load equals power supplied minus power lost in transmission lines.

Pload = Psupply + Ploss.fix: Energy conservation: what's lost in the lines can't reach the load.
Pload = Psupply + Ploss.action: 100 W supplied, 20 W lost → 80 W delivered. Subtraction.

Pload = Psupply × Ploss.fix: Psupply = Ploss + Pload, rearranged gives Pload = Psupply − Ploss.
Pload = Psupply × Ploss.action: Energy in = energy out + energy lost. Conservation.

Pload = Psupply.fix: No transmission system is 100% efficient. Some power is always lost.
Pload = Psupply.action: Only true if Rline = 0, which is physically impossible.

persistent.gap: You're not applying energy conservation to circuits.
persistent.action: Track power through 5 transmission systems: in = out + lost.

transformer_purpose.name: Purpose of Transformers
transformer_purpose.formula: Step up V → reduce I → reduce I² losses
transformer_purpose.correct: Step-up transformers increase voltage to reduce current in transmission lines, which reduces I² losses.

increase power for transmission.fix: P1 = P2 for ideal transformers. They change the V/I ratio, not total power.
increase power for transmission.action: P = VI. If V doubles, I halves. P stays the same.

increase current for transmission.error: Opposite. We want LESS current to reduce losses.
increase current for transmission.fix: Ploss = I²R. Lower current → much lower losses.
increase current for transmission.action: Why transmit at high voltage? To use LOW current.

convert DC to AC.error: Transformers only work with AC. They don't convert DC to AC.
convert DC to AC.fix: Transformers transfer power between AC circuits via changing magnetic flux.
convert DC to AC.action: DC has constant current → no changing flux → no induction.

persistent.gap: You don't understand why high-voltage transmission is efficient.
persistent.action: Calculate Ploss for same power at 1000 V vs 100 V with same resistance.

step_up_transformer.name: Step-Up Transformer Action
step_up_transformer.correct: Step-up transformers have more turns in secondary, increasing voltage and decreasing current proportionally.

more turns in primary.fix: Step-UP: more turns in secondary (N2 > N1) → higher voltage out.
more turns in primary.action: V2/V1 = N2/N1. If N2 > N1, then V2 > V1 (stepped up).

increases both voltage and current.fix: P1 = P2 means V1I1 = V2I2. If V increases, I must decrease.
increases both voltage and current.action: Can't get more power out than in. Energy conservation.

only works with DC.error: Transformers require changing flux, so AC only.
only works with DC.fix: DC produces constant flux → no EMF induced → transformer fails.
only works with DC.action: Faraday's law: EMF = −NΔΦ/Δt. No change in Φ → no EMF.

persistent.gap: You're confusing step-up and step-down transformer properties.
persistent.action: Make a table: turns ratio, voltage ratio, current ratio for step-up vs step-down.

step_down_transformer.name: Step-Down Transformer Action
step_down_transformer.correct: Step-down transformers have fewer turns in secondary, decreasing voltage and increasing current.

more turns in secondary.fix: Step-DOWN: fewer turns in secondary (N2 < N1) → lower voltage out.
more turns in secondary.action: V2/V1 = N2/N1. If N2 < N1, then V2 < V1 (stepped down).

decreases both voltage and current.fix: V1I1 = V2I2. If V decreases, I must increase.
decreases both voltage and current.action: Power in = power out. Lower V needs higher I for same P.

loses power in the process.fix: P1 = P2 for ideal transformers. Real ones are ~95-99% efficient.
loses power in the process.action: VCE assumes ideal transformers unless stated otherwise.

persistent.gap: You're not applying transformer ratios correctly.
persistent.action: Calculate V2 and I2 for 5 different transformer problems.

efficiency_improvement.name: Efficiency Improvement with Transformers
efficiency_improvement.formula: ↑V by factor n → ↓I by n → ↓Ploss by n²
efficiency_improvement.correct: Stepping up voltage by factor n reduces current by n and power loss by n² (because Ploss ∝ I²).

reduces power loss by factor n.error: It's n², not n, because of the I² relationship.
reduces power loss by factor n.action: If I becomes I/10, then I² becomes I²/100.

increases power delivered.error: Total power from generator doesn't change.
increases power delivered.fix: Less is LOST, so more reaches the load. But Psupply is unchanged.
increases power delivered.action: Pload = Psupply − Ploss. Lower Ploss → higher Pload.

has no effect on efficiency.error: This is the main reason we use high-voltage transmission.
has no effect on efficiency.fix: High voltage transmission dramatically reduces losses.
has no effect on efficiency.action: Calculate: 100 V vs 10000 V transmission. Compare losses.

persistent.gap: You don't understand the squared relationship between current and losses.
persistent.action: Work through complete example: same power at 100 V vs 1000 V.

ac_vs_dc_transmission.name: AC vs DC Transmission
ac_vs_dc_transmission.formula: AC can be transformed; DC cannot (easily)
ac_vs_dc_transmission.correct: AC is preferred for long-distance transmission because transformers can easily change voltage levels, reducing losses.

DC is more efficient.error: Without easy voltage transformation, DC transmission had high losses historically.
DC is more efficient.fix: AC + transformers allow high-voltage transmission with low losses.
DC is more efficient.action: Modern HVDC exists but requires expensive converters.

transformers work with DC.error: Transformers require changing magnetic flux to induce EMF.
transformers work with DC.fix: DC produces constant current → constant flux → no induction.
transformers work with DC.action: Faraday's law: EMF = −NΔΦ/Δt. Constant Φ means ΔΦ/Δt = 0.

there's no difference.error: AC can be easily transformed; DC requires complex converters.
there's no difference.fix: AC's ability to be transformed is the main reason it's used for transmission.
there's no difference.action: Historical AC vs DC 'war' was won by AC because of transformers.

persistent.gap: You don't understand why AC dominates power transmission.
persistent.action: Research the 'War of Currents' and why AC won for transmission.
